all_paragraphs: I’m a data scientist for a mobile application. As a data scientist, you will often draw a random sample from the population to conduct experiments or analyses. With the random sample, you make statistical inferences to the larger population.

For example, as a mobile app data scientist, during an AB Test, I will draw a random sample of all users who installed the mobile app and I will quantify the probability of a user coming back after one week the user installs the app.

This probability that I use will most likely be an expected value, which is the average value of a random variable. It is important to understand this term called Random Variable. Simply, a random variable means quantifying an outcome for a random process. So what does this have to do with an article about probability distribution?
“A list of all possible values of a random variable, along with their probabilities, is called a probability distribution.” — Statistics Essentials For Dummies

Probability distribution will differ depending on the what type of distribution it is. I’m not going to cover all types of distributions, but I will cover what I believe are the most common. There are two overarching types called discrete and continuous. I’ll cover a probability distribution that falls under each type.

Normally, you will never have to calculate these by hand with all the tools out there to help you. However, it’s good to have the foundational knowledge of the tools you’re using and understand what’s going on under the hood to be a good data scientist.

The normal distribution is probably one of the most common distribution you will see. It has what you call a bell-shaped distribution as shown below. The actual distribution might not look completely the same, but you will see the distribution has one main peak with rounds smooth curves on both sides.

It is one of the most important distributions because many real-world experiments utilize the the normal distribution whether it is AB tests in the corporate world or an experiment within a research institution. This is largely due to the central limit theorem, which assumes as the sample size becomes bigger and bigger, the distribution will take on a normal shape.
